learning_outcomes.description: Apply advanced knowledge of bacterial and fungal genetics to analyse genetic regulatory systems and development.
Compare and contrast cellular organization and regulatory mechanisms across bacteria, fungi, and archaea.
Analyse environmental sensing systems and communication mechanisms, including quorum sensing and stress responses.
Analyse virulence mechanisms employed by bacterial pathogens and evaluate host-pathogen interactions.
Differentiate between bacterial persistence and resistance mechanisms and evaluate major antibiotic classes, their targets, and resistance strategies.
Execute and adapt molecular microbiology techniques for investigating gene function, including cloning, transformation, and gene expression.
Design and implement recombinant protein expression and purification strategies.
Apply antimicrobial screening methodologies to identify and evaluate potential therapeutic compounds.
Maintain scientifically rigorous laboratory documentation according to professional standards.
Communicate experimental findings effectively through written reports and oral presentations, demonstrating critical analysis of results and their significance.

assessments.task_description:
A Pass will be awarded based on tutor assessment of laboratory participation and performance each week throughout the semester. A Pass or Fail will be given each week on the day of the class. The Pass for the whole semester's classes will be based on participation and performance throughout the semester. If a student is unable to attend a practical session they must complete the online exercises pertaining to the missed material. Tutors will be informed when online exercises are complete and will record a PASS mark for that week.

assessments.task_description:
A written report to be completed based on this practical module. This report will be in the form of a short scientific paper, which must contain title, authors, abstract, introduction, materials and methods, results, and discussion sections. Electronic versions of the report must be submitted to Turnitin on the due date.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
